I'm reading a lot of ignorance about this front; it was a lot important during the WW1.
I can suggest you to read some books like "Das Ende der alten Armee" by Fritz Weber that talks about the whole front situation till the italian win in 1918, from the Austrian part.
Or "A Year on the High Plateau (Un anno sull'altipiano) " by Emilio Lussu, that talks about some battles from the italian view.

You plan to start at a certain time so all of your units attack at once, rather than having someone start early and tip off the other side that you're starting a major attack and they should reinforce. Obviously if the start time leaks you're fucked though xD.

My grandfather ( Patsy Anastasio) fought on this front from 1917-1918. When my mother was born (November 18,1917) in Molochio, which is in Calabria, my grandfather was refused a pass to return to his wife and child. He went AWOL, was arrested and returned to his unit. Ultimately the sergeant who refused to give my grandfather his pass was demoted. Grandpa immigrated to the USA in 1920. Seven years later my mother, her brother and my grandmother came over.

Actually Austo-hungarian empire was NOT a nation state, but country with mixture of different nations (Germans, Austrians, Czech, Hungarians, Slovene, Croatian,...) living together. 

In addition to this video, I must say that majority of soliders in this battle front (Isonzo-Soča river) was ethnic Slovenians alongside with all the others. They were defending their homeland (present day Slovenia) agains Italian occupation....

Basically, this is what happened:  Holy Roman Empire was a pathetic 'empire', and Austria, which was 'part' of it, was essentially independent.  The kingdom of Hungary was split in half, half went to Austria and half to the Ottomans.  The Ottomans were then kicked out, and Austria took over.  Then the HLE disbanded, Austria became its own empire, and Hungarians weren't thrilled.  They attempted a civil war, lost, and the resulting treaty made the Austrian-Hungarian Empire as a compromise.
